description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers fluently, including signed number rules

coreConcepts: Adding integers using number line model
Subtracting integers by adding the opposite
Multiplying/dividing: same signs = positive, different signs = negative
Zero pairs and additive inverses
commonMistakes: Confusing subtraction of negatives: 5 - (-3) is NOT 5 - 3
Forgetting sign rules when multiplying two negatives
Treating -5 + 3 as -(5 + 3) instead of -5 + 3 = -2
teachingTips: Use number lines extensively before moving to rules
Have students verbalize the sign rule before computing
Spiral integer operations into every subsequent unit

description: Perform operations with fractions and decimals, including dividing fractions and converting between forms

coreConcepts: Dividing fractions: multiply by the reciprocal (keep-change-flip)
Finding common denominators for adding/subtracting fractions
Converting between fractions, decimals, and percents
Mixed number operations
commonMistakes: Flipping the wrong fraction when dividing
Adding fractions by adding numerators AND denominators
Not simplifying final answers
teachingTips: Use fraction bars and area models before abstract rules
Connect fractions to division: 3/4 means 3 divided by 4
Practice converting between all three forms daily

description: Combine like terms and use the distributive property to simplify algebraic expressions

coreConcepts: Like terms: same variable and same exponent
Combining like terms by adding/subtracting coefficients
Distributive property: a(b + c) = ab + ac
Constants vs. variable terms
commonMistakes: Combining unlike terms: 3x + 2y ≠ 5xy
Forgetting to distribute to ALL terms inside parentheses
Dropping negative signs when distributing a negative
teachingTips: Color-code like terms to build visual identification
Practice distribution with negatives extensively
Use algebra tiles for tactile learners

description: Solve simple one-step and two-step equations using inverse operations

coreConcepts: Inverse operations: addition/subtraction, multiplication/division
Isolate the variable by undoing operations in reverse order
Check your solution by substituting back
Two-step equations: undo addition/subtraction first, then multiplication/division
commonMistakes: Performing different operations on each side of the equation
Forgetting to apply the operation to BOTH sides
In 2x + 3 = 11, dividing 11 by 2 first instead of subtracting 3
teachingTips: Use balance model: whatever you do to one side, do to the other
Always verify solutions by plugging back in
Build from one-step to two-step gradually

description: Plot and identify points in all four quadrants, understand ordered pairs and axis labels

coreConcepts: Ordered pairs (x, y): x is horizontal, y is vertical
Four quadrants and their sign patterns
Origin is (0, 0)
Reflections across axes
commonMistakes: Reversing x and y coordinates
Confusing which axis is which
Plotting in the wrong quadrant with negative coordinates
teachingTips: Use 'run before you jump' mnemonic: x first (horizontal), then y (vertical)
Practice plotting in all four quadrants, not just Quadrant I
Connect to real contexts: maps, game boards

description: Add and subtract rational numbers including fractions, decimals, and mixed numbers with different signs

coreConcepts: Adding rational numbers on a number line
Additive inverses: a + (-a) = 0
Subtracting = adding the opposite: a - b = a + (-b)
Finding common denominators for rational number addition
commonMistakes: Treating 3 - (-5) as 3 - 5 instead of 3 + 5
Losing track of signs with fractions: -1/3 + 2/3 = 1/3, not -3/3
Not converting to common denominators before adding
teachingTips: Number line is the go-to model: show direction for positive/negative
Practice 'keep-change-change' for subtraction problems
Emphasize that subtraction is always adding the opposite

description: Multiply and divide rational numbers, apply sign rules, and convert between forms

coreConcepts: Same signs → positive product/quotient
Different signs → negative product/quotient
Multiplying fractions: multiply straight across
Dividing fractions: multiply by the reciprocal
commonMistakes: (-3)(-4) = -12 (forgetting negative times negative is positive)
Dividing fractions by flipping the wrong one
Not simplifying before multiplying (missing cross-cancellation)
teachingTips: Drill sign rules until automatic: same = positive, different = negative
Connect to repeated addition for why negative × negative = positive

description: Solve real-world problems involving rational numbers: temperature, money, elevation, and distance

coreConcepts: Temperature change: rising = positive, falling = negative
Money: deposits = positive, withdrawals = negative
Elevation: above sea level = positive, below = negative
Choosing the right operation for the context
commonMistakes: Mixing up which value is negative in context problems
Not reading carefully whether the problem asks for change or final value
Dropping negative signs in multi-step word problems
teachingTips: Have students identify positive/negative BEFORE computing
Use vertical number lines for elevation and temperature
Make students write the expression before solving

description: Understand and use absolute value to represent distance from zero and between numbers

coreConcepts: |a| = distance from a to 0 on the number line
Absolute value is always non-negative
Distance between two numbers: |a - b|
Opposite numbers have the same absolute value: |-5| = |5| = 5
commonMistakes: Thinking absolute value means 'make it positive' (it means distance)
Computing |-3 + 5| as |-3| + |5| = 8 instead of |2| = 2
Confusing |a - b| with |a| - |b|
teachingTips: Always ground absolute value in the number line distance model
Use real-world distance contexts: 'How far apart are floors -2 and 3?'
Emphasize: evaluate INSIDE first, then take absolute value

description: Convert word phrases and sentences into algebraic expressions and equations

coreConcepts: Key words: sum/more/increased → addition, difference/less/decreased → subtraction
Product/times → multiplication, quotient/divided → division
'Is' or 'equals' → = sign
Choosing a variable and defining what it represents
commonMistakes: '5 less than x' is x - 5, NOT 5 - x
'Twice a number increased by 3' is 2x + 3, NOT 2(x + 3)
Not defining what the variable represents before writing the expression
teachingTips: Have students underline key words and circle numbers/unknowns
Practice translating BOTH directions: words → algebra AND algebra → words
'Less than' and 'subtracted from' reverse the order — drill this

description: Use the distributive property and combine like terms to simplify complex expressions with rational coefficients

coreConcepts: Distribute with negative and fractional coefficients
Combine like terms with rational numbers
Factor common factors from expressions
Recognize equivalent expressions
commonMistakes: Not distributing the negative: -(2x - 3) = -2x + 3, NOT -2x - 3
Adding coefficients of unlike terms
Dropping terms when expressions get long
teachingTips: Build up from simple to complex: integers → fractions → negatives
Have students check equivalence by substituting a test value
Practice distributing negatives as a standalone skill

description: Solve multi-step equations involving distribution, combining like terms, and variables on both sides

coreConcepts: Distribute first, then combine like terms
Move variables to one side, constants to the other
Equations with fractions: multiply through by the LCD
Check solutions by substituting back into the original equation
commonMistakes: Distributing but forgetting to combine like terms
Moving terms across the equals sign without changing the sign
Not distributing to ALL terms inside parentheses
teachingTips: Teach a consistent procedure: distribute → combine → move → solve → check
Color-code steps to track operations
Gradually introduce fractions and decimals in equations

description: Solve, graph, and interpret inequalities including the sign-flip rule for negative multiplication/division

coreConcepts: Inequality symbols: <, >, ≤, ≥ and their meanings
Solving inequalities: same process as equations
CRITICAL: flip the sign when multiplying or dividing by a NEGATIVE
Graphing on a number line: open vs. closed circles, shading direction
commonMistakes: Forgetting to flip the inequality when dividing by a negative
Using a closed circle when the inequality is strict (< or >)
Shading in the wrong direction on the number line
teachingTips: Demonstrate the flip rule with a concrete example: 2 < 6, multiply both by -1: -2 > -6
Have students test a value from their solution set to verify
Connect to real-world contexts: 'You need MORE than $50'

description: Calculate unit rates and use them to compare quantities and make decisions

coreConcepts: Rate = ratio comparing two different units
Unit rate = rate with denominator of 1 ('per one')
Divide to find unit rate: 120 miles / 3 hours = 40 mph
Use unit rates to compare: which is the better deal?
commonMistakes: Dividing in the wrong order: price ÷ ounces, not ounces ÷ price
Not including units in the answer
Comparing rates with different units without converting
teachingTips: Always label units: 'dollars per ounce' not just a number
Use grocery store and speed contexts — students relate to these
Practice 'which is the better deal?' problems for engagement

description: Set up and solve proportions using cross-multiplication and scaling strategies

coreConcepts: Proportion: two equal ratios (a/b = c/d)
Cross-multiply to solve: ad = bc
Scale factor: multiply both parts of a ratio by the same number
Verify proportionality by checking cross products
commonMistakes: Setting up ratios with mismatched units (miles/hours = gallons/minutes)
Cross-multiplying when NOT in a proportion setup
Forgetting to check if the proportion makes sense in context
teachingTips: Label both ratios clearly before cross-multiplying
Use tables to organize proportional reasoning
Build from simple scaling before introducing cross-multiplication

description: Use scale factors to find actual and model dimensions from scale drawings and maps

coreConcepts: Scale = ratio of drawing dimension to actual dimension
Set up proportions: drawing/actual = scale/1
Scale factor > 1 = enlargement, < 1 = reduction
Finding area with scale: area scales by the SQUARE of the scale factor
commonMistakes: Mixing up which dimension is the drawing vs. actual
Using the linear scale factor for area (should be squared)
Not converting units when the scale uses different units
teachingTips: Use actual classroom objects and have students create scale drawings
Maps are the most relatable context — use real map distances
Highlight that area scales by k² with a concrete example

description: Solve real-world percent problems: discounts, tax, tips, markups, and commissions

coreConcepts: Percent = part/whole × 100
Discount: sale price = original × (1 - rate)
Tax/tip: total = original × (1 + rate)
Markup: selling price = cost × (1 + markup rate)
commonMistakes: Computing 20% off $50 as $50 - 20 = $30 (should be $50 × 0.20 = $10 off)
Adding tax to the discounted price in wrong order for multi-step problems
Confusing percent OF a number with percent change
teachingTips: Use the multiplier approach: 25% off = multiply by 0.75
Shopping contexts are highly engaging — use real prices
Practice: 'Is tax calculated on the original or sale price?'

description: Calculate and interpret percent increase and decrease in real-world contexts

coreConcepts: Percent change = (new - original) / original × 100
Positive result = increase, negative = decrease
The original value is ALWAYS the denominator
Successive percent changes: multiply the multipliers
commonMistakes: Using the new value as the denominator instead of the original
Thinking a 10% increase then 10% decrease gets back to the original (it doesn't)
Confusing absolute change with percent change
teachingTips: Use the formula AND the multiplier method — students should know both
The '10% up then 10% down' problem is eye-opening — lead with it
Connect to real data: population changes, price changes, scores

description: Determine if a relationship is proportional from tables, graphs, and equations

coreConcepts: Table test: all y/x ratios are equal
Graph test: straight line through the origin
Equation test: form y = kx (no added constant)
Non-proportional: y = mx + b where b ≠ 0
commonMistakes: Thinking any straight line is proportional (must pass through origin)
Checking only one ratio in a table instead of all of them
Confusing y = 3x + 2 (NOT proportional) with y = 3x (proportional)
teachingTips: Use all three representations side by side: table, graph, equation
Start with obviously proportional and non-proportional examples
'Does it go through the origin?' is the quick check for graphs

description: Find and interpret the constant of proportionality (k) from tables, graphs, equations, and contexts

coreConcepts: k = y/x for any row in a proportional table
k is the unit rate in context
k is the slope of the line in the graph
k is the coefficient in y = kx
commonMistakes: Computing x/y instead of y/x
Not connecting k to the unit rate in the problem context
Thinking k must be a whole number
teachingTips: Connect k to unit rate explicitly: 'k = 3 means 3 dollars per pound'
Find k from every representation and show they match
Use contexts where k has clear meaning (speed, price per item)

description: Write equations in the form y = kx to represent proportional relationships

coreConcepts: Find k from the context or data, then write y = kx
Use the equation to find unknown values
Interpret the equation in context
Connect to tables and graphs
commonMistakes: Writing y = x + k instead of y = kx
Not defining what x and y represent in context
Using k as an additive constant instead of a multiplier
teachingTips: Start from a table: find k, then write the equation
Have students predict values using their equation and verify
Compare to y = mx + b to preview slope-intercept form

description: Graph proportional relationships and interpret points on the graph including (0,0) and the unit rate point

coreConcepts: Proportional graph: straight line through the origin
The point (1, k) represents the unit rate
Plot from a table: each (x, y) pair is a point
Slope of the line = constant of proportionality = unit rate
commonMistakes: Not starting the line at the origin
Plotting points correctly but not connecting with a straight line
Mixing up x and y when reading coordinates
teachingTips: Always start by plotting the origin and the unit rate point
Use graph paper — sloppy graphs lead to errors
Have students read coordinates FROM a graph as well as plot them

description: Calculate area and circumference of circles, and review area of triangles, parallelograms, and trapezoids

coreConcepts: Circle area: A = πr²
Circumference: C = 2πr = πd
Triangle area: A = ½bh
Parallelogram: A = bh, Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h
commonMistakes: Using diameter instead of radius in A = πr² (or vice versa for C = πd)
Forgetting to square the radius: πr² ≠ πr × 2
Confusing area and circumference (square units vs. linear units)
teachingTips: Use physical models: measure real circles with string
Emphasize units: area is always in square units, perimeter in linear units
Practice with both exact (leave π) and decimal answers

description: Find the area of complex shapes by decomposing into rectangles, triangles, and circles

coreConcepts: Decompose: break into rectangles, triangles, semicircles
Add areas of parts for shapes made of pieces
Subtract areas for shapes with holes or cutouts
Use given dimensions to find missing measurements
commonMistakes: Using the wrong height for triangles in composite figures
Adding when they should subtract (e.g., rectangle with semicircle removed)
Missing a piece of the composite shape
teachingTips: Draw dotted lines to show the decomposition visually
Label each sub-shape with its own dimensions
Practice both addition (L-shapes) and subtraction (holes) composites

description: Calculate surface area using nets and formulas for prisms and pyramids

coreConcepts: Surface area = total area of all faces
Use nets to visualize and organize faces
Rectangular prism: SA = 2(lw + lh + wh)
Triangular prism: 2 triangular faces + 3 rectangular faces
commonMistakes: Forgetting a face (especially the base of a pyramid)
Confusing surface area with volume
Using slant height vs. perpendicular height incorrectly for pyramids
teachingTips: Build nets from paper — folding makes the concept click
Organize work in a table: Face | Shape | Area
Label 3D diagrams with ALL dimensions before calculating

description: Calculate volume of prisms and right cylinders using V = Bh

coreConcepts: Volume = Base area × height: V = Bh
Rectangular prism: V = lwh
Triangular prism: V = (½bh_triangle) × H
Cylinder: V = πr²h
commonMistakes: Using diameter instead of radius for cylinders
Confusing height of the base triangle with height of the prism
Using perimeter instead of area for the base
teachingTips: The big idea: volume = (area of the base) stacked up the height
Use fill-and-pour activities to build volume intuition
Always identify which measurement is the height of the 3D shape

description: Describe and identify the shapes formed by slicing 3D figures with a plane

coreConcepts: Cross-section = shape formed when a plane cuts through a solid
Slicing a rectangular prism: can produce rectangles, triangles, other shapes
Slicing a cylinder: circles (horizontal), rectangles (vertical), ellipses (diagonal)
Slicing a cone or pyramid: circles, triangles, or other shapes depending on angle
commonMistakes: Confusing the cross-section with a face of the solid
Not considering the angle of the cut
Assuming all cuts produce the same shape
teachingTips: Use play-dough or clay to physically slice shapes
Relate to real life: cutting a log, slicing a cucumber
This is more conceptual — emphasize visualization over computation

description: Distinguish between populations and samples, understand why we sample, and recognize bias

coreConcepts: Population: the entire group you want information about
Sample: a subset of the population you actually study
Why sample? Populations are often too large to study entirely
Representative sample: reflects the characteristics of the population
commonMistakes: Thinking you MUST survey everyone (census vs. sample)
Not recognizing biased samples (e.g., surveying only friends)
Confusing sample size with sample quality
teachingTips: Use school examples: surveying all 500 students vs. 50
Discuss real polls and surveys — how were they collected?
Introduce bias with obviously flawed examples first

description: Understand why random sampling produces representative results and identify sampling methods

coreConcepts: Random sample: every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected
Random sampling reduces bias
Larger random samples give more reliable estimates
Convenience samples and voluntary response samples are often biased
commonMistakes: Thinking 'random' means 'haphazard' — it means equal chance
Not recognizing convenience sampling as biased
Assuming a large biased sample is better than a small random one
teachingTips: Simulate: draw names from a hat vs. picking volunteers
Compare results from different sampling methods — show the bias
Connect to real examples: phone polls, online surveys, taste tests

description: Compare two groups using measures of center (mean, median) and variability (range, MAD, IQR)

coreConcepts: Mean: add all values, divide by count
Median: middle value when data is ordered
Range: max - min (simple spread measure)
MAD (Mean Absolute Deviation): average distance from the mean
commonMistakes: Forgetting to order data before finding the median
Comparing means without considering variability
Not computing MAD correctly: must use absolute values
teachingTips: Use dot plots and box plots to visualize before computing
Compare with context: 'Class A scores higher ON AVERAGE, but Class B is more consistent'
Teach that center + spread together tell the full story

description: Use sample data to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations

coreConcepts: Inference: a conclusion drawn from evidence (not certainty)
Use measures of center and variability to support claims
Compare distributions visually using dot plots or box plots
Larger differences between groups + smaller variability = stronger inference
commonMistakes: Making absolute claims ('Group A IS better') instead of qualified ones ('evidence suggests')
Ignoring variability when drawing conclusions
Not referencing specific numbers to support their inference
teachingTips: Teach claim-evidence-reasoning framework for written responses
Use overlapping vs. non-overlapping distributions to show strength of evidence
Practice: 'What can we say? What CAN'T we say?'

description: Calculate the probability of simple events as a ratio of favorable to total outcomes

coreConcepts: P(event) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes
Probability ranges from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain)
Express as fraction, decimal, or percent
Complement: P(not A) = 1 - P(A)
commonMistakes: Probability greater than 1 (impossible — check your ratio)
Not counting total outcomes correctly
Confusing 'favorable' with 'unfavorable' outcomes
teachingTips: Start with familiar objects: coins, dice, spinners, cards
Place probabilities on a 0-to-1 number line for intuition
Always list the sample space before computing

description: Compare experimental results with theoretical predictions and understand the law of large numbers

coreConcepts: Theoretical probability: what SHOULD happen based on math
Experimental probability: what ACTUALLY happens in trials
Law of large numbers: more trials → closer to theoretical
Relative frequency: experimental probability from data
commonMistakes: Expecting experimental to match theoretical exactly in small samples
Thinking a coin 'is due' for heads after several tails (gambler's fallacy)
Not recognizing that experimental results vary from trial to trial
teachingTips: Run actual experiments: flip coins 10 times vs. 100 times
Track results on a class chart and watch convergence
Discuss: 'Is the die unfair, or did we just not roll enough?'

description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, and tree diagrams

coreConcepts: Compound event: two or more simple events combined
Sample space: list ALL possible outcomes systematically
Organized list, table, or tree diagram to count outcomes
P(compound) = favorable compound outcomes / total compound outcomes
commonMistakes: Missing outcomes when listing (not being systematic)
Counting (red, blue) and (blue, red) as the same when order matters
Multiplying probabilities when they should be listing outcomes
teachingTips: Tree diagrams are the most visual — start there
For two events, a table (grid) is often fastest
Always count total outcomes FIRST, then favorable

description: Design and use simulations (spinners, dice, random numbers) to estimate probabilities

coreConcepts: Simulation: using a model to estimate real-world probabilities
Choose a device that matches the probability (coin for 50/50, die for 1/6)
Run many trials and record results
Use relative frequency from simulation as probability estimate
commonMistakes: Choosing a simulation device that doesn't match the scenario
Not running enough trials (too few = unreliable)
Confusing the simulation model with the real situation
teachingTips: Use real dice, coins, and spinners — hands-on is essential
Design a simulation for a real question: 'What's the chance of rain 3 days in a row?'
Compare simulation results to theoretical calculations when possible

description: Substitute values into algebraic expressions and evaluate using order of operations

coreConcepts: Replace the variable with the given value (use parentheses!)
Follow order of operations: PEMDAS/GEMS
Evaluate expressions with multiple variables
Handle negative substitutions carefully: (-3)² ≠ -3²
commonMistakes: Not using parentheses when substituting negatives: 2(-3)² vs. 2 × -3²
Applying operations in wrong order after substitution
Forgetting that x² when x = -3 means (-3)² = 9, not -(3²) = -9
teachingTips: Always write parentheses around the substituted value
Use the 'replace and rewrite' strategy: show each step
Build complexity gradually: positive → negative → fraction substitutions

description: Write and solve equations for real-world problems involving geometry, percent, and multi-step contexts

coreConcepts: Read → identify unknowns → define variables → write equation → solve → check
Geometry word problems: perimeter, area, angle relationships
Percent word problems: is/of = %/100 or equation approach
Multi-step problems: organize information before writing equations
commonMistakes: Jumping to computation without setting up an equation
Defining the variable incorrectly (what does x actually represent?)
Not checking if the answer makes sense in context
teachingTips: Require students to define variables in words before writing equations
Use the 'does my answer make sense?' check as a mandatory final step
Mix geometry and percent contexts to show equations work everywhere

description: Understand functions as input/output rules, identify rules from tables, and evaluate functions

coreConcepts: Function: a rule that assigns exactly one output to each input
Input → Rule → Output (function machine model)
Find the rule from a table: look for the pattern between x and y
Use the rule to find missing values
commonMistakes: Not checking ALL rows in a table — one pattern that works for two rows might not work for all
Writing additive rules when the pattern is multiplicative
Confusing functions with proportional relationships (not all functions are y = kx)
teachingTips: Use the 'function machine' metaphor: input goes in, rule happens, output comes out
Start with simple rules: y = 2x, y = x + 3, then build to y = 2x + 1
This is a PREVIEW of 8th grade — keep it intuitive, not overly formal

description: Identify, extend, and write rules for arithmetic and geometric patterns and sequences

coreConcepts: Arithmetic sequence: add the same number each time (common difference)
Geometric sequence: multiply by the same number each time (common ratio)
Writing the rule: use the pattern to find the nth term
Connect to function tables: position (n) → value
commonMistakes: Confusing arithmetic (add) with geometric (multiply) patterns
Off-by-one errors when finding the nth term
Not checking the rule against ALL given terms
teachingTips: Use visual patterns (dot arrays, tile patterns) alongside number sequences
Ask: 'What changes each time? By how much?'
This bridges naturally to linear functions in 8th grade
